metadata.description: Comprehensive error codes database for industrial power generation, control systems, engines, alternators, and solar inverters - complete professional industrial diagnostic reference

deepsea.name: DEEPSEA Controllers
deepsea.description: Comprehensive diagnostic codes for DEEPSEA controller series covering manual start, auto mains failure, synchronization, and advanced control modules

DSE31XX.name: DSE31XX Series - Manual & Auto Start Control
DSE31XX.description: Entry-level to mid-range manual and automatic start control modules for genset applications

possibleCauses: Battery discharge below minimum threshold (< 8.5V DC for 12V systems, <17V for 24V systems)
Defective battery cells or internal short circuit reducing voltage output
Battery charger malfunction, disconnected, or AC input power failure
Excessive parasitic load draining battery during standby periods
Corroded or loose battery terminals causing voltage drop under load
Aging battery with reduced capacity (typically after 3-5 years service life)
Battery cable resistance causing voltage drop during cranking
Battery temperature effects - cold weather reducing available capacity
solutions: 1. Immediately measure battery voltage at terminals with multimeter - should read 12.5-13V for healthy 12V battery at rest
2. Check battery charger output voltage - should provide 13.8-14.4V DC for float charging 12V batteries
3. Load test battery using carbon pile tester - apply 50% of CCA rating for 15 seconds, voltage should not drop below 9.6V for 12V battery
4. Inspect and clean battery terminals with wire brush, apply anti-corrosion compound or dielectric grease
5. Check for parasitic loads - disconnect negative terminal and measure current draw with ammeter (should be <50mA for typical genset)
6. Test individual cell specific gravity with hydrometer - readings should be 1.265 or higher and within 0.050 of each other
7. Replace battery if specific gravity readings below 1.200, age exceeds 4 years, or load test fails
8. Verify battery charger AC input power present and fuse/breaker not tripped
9. Check battery cable connections and resistance - clean and tighten all connections
10. Reset controller fault after battery voltage stabilizes above 11.5V minimum
requiredTools: Digital multimeter (TRMS) with DC voltage and current measurement
Battery load tester (carbon pile type) rated for battery capacity
Hydrometer for specific gravity testing (0-30°C compensating type)
Wire brush or battery terminal cleaning tool
Dielectric grease or anti-corrosion compound
Battery terminal puller (if corroded)
DC clamp ammeter for parasitic load testing
safetyWarnings: DANGER: Battery contains sulfuric acid electrolyte - wear protective eyewear, face shield, and acid-resistant gloves
WARNING: Hydrogen gas generation during charging creates explosion hazard - ensure adequate ventilation, absolutely no sparks, flames, or smoking
CAUTION: Do not disconnect battery while engine running - may damage alternator diodes and voltage regulator
CRITICAL: Maintain proper polarity when connecting - reverse polarity will instantly destroy controller electronics and alternator diodes
NOTICE: Dispose of old batteries at approved recycling center - contains lead and acid hazardous materials

codes.description: Oil Pressure Sensor Failure or Out of Range
possibleCauses: Oil pressure sensor wiring harness damaged, chafed, or disconnected at connector
Oil pressure sensor internal failure - typically occurs after 5000-8000 operating hours
Contaminated sensor threads preventing proper electrical ground connection to engine block
Incorrect sensor type installed - wrong resistance range or voltage output for controller input
ECU analog input channel malfunction or incorrect calibration
Electrical noise interference on sensor signal wire from nearby high-current cables
Sensor diaphragm ruptured allowing oil leak and sensor failure
Sensor mounting boss threads damaged or cross-threaded
solutions: 1. Verify sensor wiring continuity - measure resistance between sensor connector pins and ECU input terminals (should be <5 ohms)
2. Check sensor output voltage or current with engine running - 0-5V DC or 4-20mA typical depending on sensor type
3. Compare sensor reading with mechanical oil pressure gauge installed at same location using T-fitting adapter
4. At idle speed, oil pressure typically 10-30 PSI; at rated speed should be 40-80 PSI for most diesel engines
5. Inspect sensor threads and mounting boss for oil leakage, contamination, or damage
6. Verify sensor specification matches controller requirements - check part number against manual
7. Test sensor resistance if variable resistance type - should change smoothly with pressure variation
8. Replace sensor if resistance check shows open circuit, erratic readings, or physical damage observed
9. Apply Teflon tape or thread sealant to sensor threads - install to 15-25 ft-lbs torque specification
10. Route sensor signal wire away from high-current cables, use shielded wire if EMI interference suspected
11. Calibrate controller input channel after sensor replacement using known pressure reference or mechanical gauge
requiredTools: Mechanical oil pressure gauge kit (0-150 PSI range minimum)
T-fitting adapter (1/8" NPT or 1/4" NPT depending on engine model)
Digital multimeter with AC/DC voltage, resistance, and current measurement
Teflon tape or approved thread sealant for oil pressure sensors
Torque wrench (0-50 ft-lbs range, 15-25 ft-lbs typical for sensor installation)
Shielded signal cable if replacement needed
Oil drain pan for oil spillage during sensor removal
Deep socket set for sensor removal/installation
safetyWarnings: WARNING: Engine oil temperature can exceed 200-250°F - allow minimum 30 minutes cooling before sensor removal to prevent severe burns
CAUTION: Ensure engine completely stopped and oil pressure fully relieved before removing sensor to prevent oil spray injury
NOTICE: Have oil collection pan ready - expect 0.5-1 quart spillage during sensor removal depending on engine design
WARNING: Do not over-torque sensor installation - can crack sensor housing or damage aluminum threads in engine block
CRITICAL: Never operate engine with oil pressure sensor removed - massive oil loss will occur causing engine seizure

codes.description: Coolant Temperature High Alarm - Overheat Condition
possibleCauses: Insufficient coolant level in radiator, expansion tank, or deaeration tank
Coolant pump mechanical failure, impeller erosion, or slipping drive belt
Thermostat stuck closed preventing coolant circulation to radiator
Radiator core blocked externally by debris, dirt, insects, or internally by scale, sediment, corrosion products
Cooling fan malfunction - broken fan belt (belt-driven) or electric fan motor failure
Collapsed or restricted coolant hoses reducing flow
Head gasket failure allowing combustion gases into cooling system, creating air pockets and pressure
Incorrect coolant mixture ratio - insufficient antifreeze concentration reducing boiling point and corrosion protection
Radiator cap pressure relief failure - not maintaining system pressure
Heat exchanger fouling in liquid-cooled systems
Excessive engine load beyond design rating
solutions: 1. Immediately shut down engine if temperature exceeds 220°F to prevent catastrophic damage
2. Allow engine to cool minimum 30 minutes before opening cooling system - never remove radiator cap when hot
3. Check coolant level in radiator and expansion tank - add 50/50 antifreeze/water mixture to proper level
4. Inspect radiator cap pressure rating (typically 13-17 PSI) and test with pressure cap tester for proper holding pressure
5. Perform cooling system pressure test to 15-17 PSI - watch for external leaks at hoses, gaskets, pump seal, and radiator
6. Check coolant pump operation - look for leakage at weep hole indicating bearing/seal failure, listen for bearing noise
7. Verify thermostat operation - remove and test in heated water bath, should begin opening at rated temperature (typically 180-195°F)
8. Inspect radiator core for external blockage - clean with compressed air in reverse direction (back-flush)
9. Check cooling fan operation - for belt-driven fans, belt tension should deflect 0.5 inch maximum under thumb pressure
10. For electric cooling fans, verify 12/24V supply voltage and fan motor operation, check current draw against specification
11. Test for combustion gases in coolant using chemical test kit - blue to yellow color change indicates head gasket leak
12. Measure coolant concentration with hydrometer or refractometer - should be 50/50 for -34°F freeze protection
13. Flush cooling system if contaminated with rust, scale, or oil - use commercial flush chemical and reverse flush procedure
14. Check coolant hoses for soft spots, cracks, or internal collapse - replace any suspect hoses
15. Verify correct radiator size for engine power rating and ambient temperature conditions
requiredTools: Coolant hydrometer or digital refractometer for concentration testing
Radiator pressure tester kit with adapter caps
Radiator cap pressure tester
Infrared temperature gun (non-contact pyrometer) 0-500°F range
Belt tension gauge
Combustion gas test kit (chemical detector)
Cooling system flush equipment and chemicals
Torque wrench for thermostat housing bolts
Coolant recycling/fill equipment
Compressed air source for radiator cleaning
codes.estimatedRepairTime: 90-180 minutes for diagnosis and basic repairs, 4-8 hours for head gasket replacement
safetyWarnings: DANGER: Never remove radiator cap when engine hot - can cause severe scalding burns from pressurized coolant above 265°F
WARNING: Coolant temperature can exceed 220-250°F - allow minimum 30-60 minutes cooling time before opening system
CAUTION: Ethylene glycol antifreeze is highly toxic - prevent skin contact, eye contact, and ingestion
CRITICAL: Keep children and pets away - ethylene glycol has sweet taste but is deadly poison
NOTICE: Dispose of used coolant properly at approved facility - extremely toxic to animals and environment
WARNING: Keep hands and tools clear of cooling fan area - electric fans may start unexpectedly even with engine off
CAUTION: Wear safety goggles and gloves when performing pressure tests - hot coolant under pressure can spray
